hypothesis.title: Frequency-research vs Web Clip Controlled Comparison
hypothesis.question: How does tuning strategy (Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5) vs Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN) vs 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system) influence perceived consonance, roughness, and continuity in a controlled harmonic micro-study?
hypothesis.hypothesis: If we render one identical arrangement with tuning strategy (Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5) vs Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN) vs 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system) while holding all other musical factors fixed, then listener ratings will show a consistent ordering in consonance and roughness between versions, because interval-ratio alignment and temperament error distribution change partial overlap and beating behavior.
hypothesis.rationaleMd:
Selected sources converge on ratio-based and temperament-based explanations for consonance and roughness [S1, S2, S3].

The context includes explicit comma/temperament and interval evidence that supports a controlled comparison where only the tuning variable changes [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6].

Falsification criterion: if blinded ratings show no stable ordering across versions, or if roughness notes fail to cluster by version, the hypothesis is not supported.

recipe.title: Frequency-research Comparison Micro-Study
recipe.bodyMd:
## Goal
Evaluate tuning strategy (Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5) vs Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN) vs 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system) under controlled musical conditions using a blinded comparison design.

## Shared Arrangement
- Tempo: 82 BPM
- Meter: 4/4
- Length: 24-32 bars
- Keep MIDI notes, sound sources, automation, and mix balance identical across versions.

## Variable Under Test
- Change only: tuning strategy (Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5) vs Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN) vs 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system)
- Keep all non-target variables fixed.

## Evaluation
- Blind-label exports and rate: consonance, roughness/beating, and continuity.
- Annotate bar/chord locations where roughness is strongest.

Evidence basis: [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6].

parameters.value: Sustained triadic texture with fixed voicing
Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5)
Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN)

dawChecklist: Create one master MIDI arrangement template.
Freeze instrument and FX chain before rendering comparison arms.
Render Version A using Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5).
Render Version B using Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN).
Render Version C using 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system.
Match loudness across exports to remove gain bias.
Rename exports to blind labels (e.g., X/Y/Z).
Rate each version for consonance, roughness, and continuity.
Capture bar-level notes for perceptual spikes.
Summarize whether observed ordering supports or contradicts hypothesis.

protocol.listeningContext: Quiet room; repeat on headphones and monitors at fixed playback level.
protocol.listeningMethod: Blinded multi-version comparison with consistent rating rubric.
whatVaries: tuning strategy (Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 8-note scale Sβ5) vs Golden ratio algebraic tuning (φ-octave, 10-note scale SN) vs 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET) — reference system)

notes: Auto-synthesized from context pack using deterministic rule templates. Review before studio execution.
